title: 111_s2983
content: The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" allows for payroll tax forgiveness for hiring unemployed workers. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" provides a special exemption for certain individuals hired in 2010, allowing qualified employers to not apply subsection (a) of Section 3111 of the Internal Revenue Code for wages paid to qualified individuals during that year. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" exempts qualified employers from certain taxes for wages paid to qualified individuals from the day after enactment until December 31, 2010, for services performed in their trade or business. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" exempts qualified employers from certain taxes for wages paid to qualified individuals in furtherance of their exempt purpose under section 501, with definitions for qualified employer and qualified individual provided. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" defines a qualified individual as someone who starts employment with a qualified employer between February 3, 2010, and January 1, 2011, and has not worked more than 40 hours in the 60 days prior to starting the job. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" requires a qualified individual to certify they have not worked more than 40 hours in the 60 days before starting employment with a qualified employer. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" mandates that a qualified individual must not be hired to replace another employee unless the previous employee left voluntarily or for cause. Additionally, the employer can choose to opt-out of this requirement. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" allows qualified employers to elect not to apply certain subsections related to payroll tax forgiveness for wages paid to qualified individuals. The "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" allows qualified employers to elect not to include wages paid to qualified individuals in the payroll tax forgiveness provision, as per the amendments made to the Internal Revenue Code. Amounts equal to the reduction in revenues are appropriated to the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund. The amendments made by the "Hire Now Tax Cut Act of 2010" appropriate amounts to the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Trust Fund and the Federal Disability Insurance Trust Fund. The amendments apply to wages paid after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. Business credit for retention of certain newly hired individuals in 2010. The current year business credit under section 38(b) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 will be increased by $1,000 multiplied by the number of retained workers who meet certain criteria during the taxable year. A retained worker is defined as a qualified individual employed by the taxpayer at any point during the year. The term "retained worker" refers to a qualified individual employed by the taxpayer for at least 52 consecutive weeks, with wages in the last 26 weeks equaling at least 80% of the wages in the first 26 weeks.
